thread.title: Masig Island community members mourn loss of iconic Queen tree - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Masig Island community members mourn loss of iconic Queen tree - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Abc Far North
title: Masig Island community members mourn loss of iconic Queen tree - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
By Mark Rigby Posted February 23, 2017 15:50:24 Map: Torres Strait Islands 
Masig (Yorke) Island residents are mourning the loss of a giant fig tree planted in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's meeting with Torres Strait Islanders during her tour of Australia in 1954. 
For almost 63 years residents of Masig Island, about 800 kilometres north of Cairns, have revered what is often called the Queen tree. 
However, this week the tree's rotting roots gave up their tenuous hold and the iconic behemoth fell to the ground. 
Masig Island elder Dan Mosby was 13 years old when the tree was brought to the island by elders who had met with Queen Elizabeth II in Cairns the previous week. 
Mr Mosby remembered the large ceremony that was held in honour of the Queen's recognition of his people. 
He said many Torres Strait Islanders had fond memories of the tree and were upset to hear of its demise. 
"Everybody's sad, especially those people around my age and a bit older than me," he said. 
"I don't think the tree can be saved because it's split into three pieces." Tree a place for community gatherings 
Mr Mosby said the tree was considered a special place on Masig Island and Queen tree was only one of the names it was known by. 
"We call it the tree of knowledge because so many of our elders have passed away now," he said. 
"All the meetings used to happen under there â€” gatherings, feastings, everything happened under that tree." Photo: Community members have rallied to remove parts of the fallen tree that have caused damage to powerlines and other surrounding infrastructure. (Supplied: Susannah Mosby) 
In recent years, a general store was built opposite the tree, making it even more integral to everyday life on Masig Island. 
"We don't have much news [up here]. We get talkback radio and when we go home we can watch digital television, but mostly people like to yarn under that tree," Mr Mosby said. 
Although the future of what is left of the tree remains uncertain, Mr Mosby said he would like to see something done with it to remind people of its significance. 
"I'd like to see it put in such a place that people can go and have a look at it, because it's a historic tree for this island," he said. 
Masig Island community members are currently working to clear the remains of the tree from the site.
